precontext: They decided to take a trip to the countryside. Nearby, there was a small outpost that piqued their interest. They heard it was known for its outstanding features.
sentence: The big branch was very close to where they were staying.
ending: This is very convenient since they will have more to offer.
meanings_considered: a division of a stem, or secondary stem arising from the main stem of a plant
a division of some larger or more complex organization
explanation:
• The precontext mentions a "small outpost" in the countryside, making a geographical or physical structure (like a branch of a tree) unlikely, as outposts are human-made structures.  
• "Branch" as a division of an organization (e.g., a branch office) fits better with the idea of a "small outpost" that is part of a larger system, such as a government or company.  
• The ending states "this is very convenient since they will have more to offer," which suggests a functional or service-based entity, supporting the organizational meaning over a plant part.
clear_meaning_text: a division of some larger or more complex organization
raw_response:
system
